headline: Amazon could actually benefit from Trump's tariffs, analyst says
summary: Amazon (AMZN) says it never planned to display the cost associated with tariffs, as claimed in a recent report, after the White House called the move "a hostile and political act." CFRA Research senior equity research analyst Arun Sundaram joins Market Domination with Julie Hyman and Josh Lipton to discuss the impact of tariffs on Amazon, ahead of the company's first quarter results after the closing bell on Thursday.

raw.headline: Amazon could actually benefit from Trump's tariffs, analyst says
raw.summary: Amazon (AMZN) says it never planned to display the cost associated with tariffs, as claimed in a recent report, after the White House called the move "a hostile and political act." CFRA Research senior equity research analyst Arun Sundaram joins Market Domination with Julie Hyman and Josh Lipton to discuss the impact of tariffs on Amazon, ahead of the company's first quarter results after the closing bell on Thursday.

headline: Amazon is not planning to show added tariff costs next to its online product listings
summary: Amazon is not planning to list added tariff costs next to product prices on its site — despite speculation spanning from a report that claimed the e-commerce giant would soon show new import charges, as well as fiery comments from President Donald Trump's White House denouncing such a move.  The Trump administration’s reaction appeared to be based on a misinterpretation of internal plans being considered by Amazon, rather than a final decision made by the company.  Amazon's Haul service — a recently launched, low-cost storefront — “considered the idea” of listing import charges on certain products, company spokesperson Tim Doyle said in a statement sent to The Associated Press.

raw.headline: Amazon is not planning to show added tariff costs next to its online product listings
raw.summary: Amazon is not planning to list added tariff costs next to product prices on its site — despite speculation spanning from a report that claimed the e-commerce giant would soon show new import charges, as well as fiery comments from President Donald Trump's White House denouncing such a move.  The Trump administration’s reaction appeared to be based on a misinterpretation of internal plans being considered by Amazon, rather than a final decision made by the company.  Amazon's Haul service — a recently launched, low-cost storefront — “considered the idea” of listing import charges on certain products, company spokesperson Tim Doyle said in a statement sent to The Associated Press.

headline: Honeywell outlook, Adidas, Amazon & Trump: Trending Tickers
summary: Madison Mills and Explosive Options technical analyst Bob Lang examine some of the day's trending tickers on Yahoo Finance's platform during the trading session. Honeywell (HON) lifts its full-year outlook after its first quarter results beat expectations. Adidas (ADS.DE, ADDYY, ADS.HM) warns that tariffs will increase prices, opting not to raise its guidance despite a strong first quarter. Amazon (AMZN) is in the White House's crosshairs, as President Trump's Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt reacted to reports that the e-commerce giant will display the price increase associated with tariffs, saying it is "a hostile and political act." The Washington Post later reported that the company had debated making the move on its low-cost Amazon Haul site, not its main website. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Catalysts here. This post has been updated to reflect new reporting.

raw.headline: Honeywell outlook, Adidas, Amazon & Trump: Trending Tickers

Honeywell (HON) lifts its full-year outlook after its first quarter results beat expectations. Adidas (ADS.DE, ADDYY, ADS.HM) warns that tariffs will increase prices, opting not to raise its guidance despite a strong first quarter. Amazon (AMZN) is in the White House's crosshairs, as President Trump's Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt reacted to reports that the e-commerce giant will display the price increase associated with tariffs, saying it is "a hostile and political act." The Washington Post later reported that the company had debated making the move on its low-cost Amazon Haul site, not its main website. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Catalysts here. This post has been updated to reflect new reporting.

headline: White House Blasts Amazon on Report It Will Publish Tariff Hit to Products. The Stock Drops.
summary: Amazon.com  stock was down Tuesday after a report said the company would show how much of an item’s cost comes from tariffs.  The stock has dropped 16% this year, mostly on tariff worries.  At a news briefing, White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt responded to the report by saying: “This is a hostile and political act by Amazon.”

headline: Amazon says tariff pricing wasn’t planned for main site, as WH calls ’hostile act’
summary: Investing.com -- Shares of Amazon (NASDAQ:AMZN) fell over 2% in pre-open trading Tuesday after White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt said a move by the e-commerce giant to break out tariff pricing on products it sells is a "hostile and political" act. Shares have since recovered part of the decline after Amazon said tarrif pricing wasn’t being considered for the main website. The stock last traded down 1%.

raw.headline: Amazon says tariff pricing wasn’t planned for main site, as WH calls ’hostile act’

Shares have since recovered part of the decline after Amazon said tarrif pricing wasn’t being considered for the main website. The stock last traded down 1%.
